title: Will an unmanned aerial vehicle be used by a non-governmental or intra-governmental organization to deliver humanitarian aid to a conflict zone in 2017?
preds: Adjusting down for the passage of time.
It seems logical to use unmanned drones to deliver food, water or water conversion kits to areas that might not permit outside personnel.
Maybe in 2018 when Windhorse Aero put their Pouncer drone into the air.
The idea may have been suggested, but has anyone actually tried it? I don't know how serious people are aboit it, or if they even have the ability to carry through with their idea.
At this point, it's unlikely to happen - only 10% chance that it's happened already and someone will post that information. Sad I didn't have time to make it happen.
How Drone Delivery Is Saving Lives in Rural Rwanda

I don't see any news about it, and I think any company or org making this effort would be sure to publicize it ahead of time and make it clear that they need funding, donations etc., especially since this is such a hot topic in the news right now. That + the fact that it's already near years end makes it extremely unlikely that we will see an effort made this month.
I'm just going to say no at this point because there's only a month or so left in the year.

The World Food Programme, one of the first humanitarian organizations to explore the use of unmanned aerial vehicles back in 2007, hasn’t officially deployed any UAVs in responses this year. In fact, the agency’s drone count currently stands at zero.

A prototype for a disposable drone was developed, with designers claiming it could be ready for missions by the end of the year (so much for that-- it's currently in testing, and they're hoping for sometime in 2018). Their concept makes sense because no-one wants to risk expensive drones being shot down. I haven't seen anything like it elsewhere, so I'm adjusting down now that it's clear it won't be deployed by year's end.
seems to me like a terrible idea, but maybe I don't understand what is a conflict zone.

Lowering significantly due to no news from Windhorse Aero on testing the Pouncer drone https://www.windhorse.aero/?jssCart=c0c1e11e0c8368de102ac986fd39d5ca, or any other companies testing drones in conflict zones. Therefore, lowering the likelihood that an NGO or IGO will use the technology in the next 7 weeks.

Clips from article:
"Instead, the United Nations food assistance branch has been putting drones in the sky only as part of a project to establish clearer guidelines for the humanitarian sector at large.
“It’s something internally we agreed. We don’t have a guideline for using this new technology. There are a lot of questions around privacy, data protection, perceptions of the communities, accountability to affected populations … so we decided we are not going to deploy any until we sort this out and establish a practice,” said Haidar Baqir, information technology emergencies officer for the WFP’s Asia-Pacific Regional Bureau."

Available Tech: non-military UAV - (1) cargo capacity: ~20Kg (2) range: ~30min ~=15mi RT (3) Control range: (~2mi LOS) (3a) Blind/GPS flightplan onboard?
Inhibitors: (1) Tech+safety (2) Delivery/Accountability (3) Specialized personnel (operator/crew)

See @shivadiva October 9 post and comments. Agree. Up-voted 1. Dropping % for the passage of time.

Comments: Bureaucracy..... naturally ,:^(   The technology is actually proven/operational, just waiting on the will. See also @AB747 September 29 post and comments. Up-voted 1. Adjusting forecast.
Digital Trends, September 28, 'DRONES CAN HELP WHEN DISASTER STRIKES, BUT ONLY WHEN THEY’RE ALLOWED TO': https://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/rescue-drones-hurricane-flood-disaster-relief/
Clips from article:
"Bots vs. bureaucrats
Following Hurricane Harvey, a collective of drone experts known as Humanitarian Drones used DroneDeploy to map damaged areas for the National Guard and the city of Houston. The group, formed solely to help with Harvey relief efforts, was initially tasked with helping the American Red Cross with post-Harvey aid — but its efforts were hampered by an unnatural force that often wreaks havoc on innovative ideas: bureaucracy.
“Don’t attach yourself to any one organization. We learned that with the Red Cross,” Humanitarian Drones member Ty Audronis told Digital Trends. “I’m sure they’re a fantastic organization, but they’re really big, and with a big organization comes a lot of bureaucracy and a lot of opinions. So, while they were figuring out whether or not they wanted us to help them, we should’ve been out helping other people at the same time instead of waiting on them.”
Dropping forecast due to 3 months remaining.
Dropping because I feel like this would have happened by now or at least been announced.

It occurs to me that "an unmanned aerial vehicle" could in certain circles include a parachute or glider full of supplies dropped from a standard aircraft.  Presumably that isn't what anybody is interested in, so I guess I am just being a nuisance.  Disregard this traffic.

Zip Line is only delivering aid to Rwanda and Tanzania. Rwanda is definitely not a conflicting zone and won't become one, but a UN peacekeeper was killed in Tanzania recently. I should keeo an eye on things to see if things escalate, but even if it does, Zip Line might withdraw to avoid risking it's equipment. Drones can be used to drop grenades and bombs on soldiers (ISIS has done this), so drones in the wrong place at the wrong time can be shot down.

tsm has some great comments about the state of the technology so far. It looks like this is a relatively new idea which is still being tested and improved. There are already drones delivering aid, but not to conflict zones, and if aid workers are still arguing about whether this is a good idea and whether more testing is necessary, then it'll be a while before anyone is willing to risk a drone in an area where people can shoot it down. No-one wants to donate money to a charity which takes needless risks. We'll see lots of drones in peaceful places before they're sent to combat zones.
Some entrepreneur needing to whitewash their name (Mark Zuckerberg?) will do it because they can and for the publicity. It's cheaper. Yemen could be on the list also

It is very likeley, especially for natural disaster zones or zones hit by a serious disease or no access to the infrastructure. It is also likely that individuals are already using it for an organization without mentioning it.

-5%; i actually don't believe that it would be a valid option, but it takes just one organisation to disagree with that assessment and try it out in any conflict zone. so i am hesitant to reduce my forecast further.

Just noticed that owing to the way the Q is worded,  if the UN does this it won't count as a Yes.  The UN is an intergovernmental organization, not an non-governmental  or "intra-governmental" organization.  On the other hand, if the US National Security Council did this, it would be a Yes, since that is indeed an intra-governmental outfit, although not an intergovermental one.
I think y'all are a bunch of dreamers with your 90-100% probability on this question. But I do really want it to be true.
I think the issue will be finding out about it.

Maintaining forecast: 
NGO’s and intra-governmental agencies use drones to map displaced populations. With inaccessible communities in northeast Nigeria vulnerable to famine and the cholera epidemic in Yemen, the agencies may be more inclined to use drones to deliver aid in order to prevent situations from worsening. Lack of funding may make the use of drones cost prohibitive, but the technology needs testing at some point.
Moving into fall and winter months, weather will play a major factor in UAV launch timetables (accelerate or delay) going forward. Affirming forecast.

Comments: Yemen
PBS News Hour, August 4, 'PHOTOS: How aid groups are tackling Yemen’s cholera outbreak': http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/photos-aid-groups-tackling-yemens-cholera-outbreak/
Clips from PBS article:
"How widespread is the outbreak? Yemen’s Health Ministry has reported about 408,600 suspected cases of cholera and 1,885 deaths in the current outbreak, which began in October 2016. The country has seen a surge since April of 5,000 cases reported each day.
U.N. agency leaders who recently visited the Arab country are calling it the “world’s worst cholera outbreak in the midst of the world’s largest humanitarian crisis.”

The drones that many hobbyists use have low-capacity and are most likely to be used for low-weight, high-value items such as drugs.  A 1-pound package is pushing it. A 4-ounce package maybe, depending upon the distance.
Africa’s first humanitarian drone testing corridor launched in Malawi by Government and UNICEF

Comments: See @tsm June 10 post and comments. Interesting development. Upvote-1.
More....
Defence Web, June 30, 'Malawi, UNICEF launch Africa’s first humanitarian drone testing corridor': http://www.defenceweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=48408:malawi-unicef-launch-africas-first-humanitarian-drone-testing-corridor&catid=90:science-a-defence-technology&Itemid=204
Clips from article:
"Drone technology has many potential applications ... One that we have already tested in Malawi is to transport infant blood samples to laboratories for HIV testing," UNICEF Malawi Resident Representative Johannes Wedenig said at the launch in Kasungu, 100 km (60 miles) from the capital Lilongwe.
The test corridor is centred at the Kasungu Aerodrome, with a 40 km radius and focusing on three areas: generating aerial images of crisis situations, using drones to extend Wi-Fi or mobile phone signals across difficult terrain in emergencies, and delivering low-weight emergency supplies."

p of t
what's taking so long?

As stated in the FSD report, the use of drones still has strong military connotations, and until a solid framework can be developed in which UAVs can be reliably identified as non-military, I think it is unlikely that they will be used to provide humanitarian aid in a conflict zone.

There are still technical kinks about delivering stuff by drone, mostly but not all to do with safety--what happens if it encounters unexpected conditions or otherwise drops out of the sky.  Not to put too fine a point on it, these considerations matter less in a place where armed conflict has produced a humanitarian crisis; those folks are already at sufficently high risk that having a UAV fall on them is practically rounding error.  You and I should not think like that, but we are for the most part not drone manufacturers anxious to test our kit.
Will the "Humanitarian UAS Testing Corridor" count?

Comments: Perfect proving ground.
BBC News, May 22,'Yemen war: Major cholera epidemic feared, says charity': http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-39996900
Clips from article:
"Charity Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), which has set up cholera treatment centres in the country, also fears the outbreak will spiral out of control.
"Before the outbreak, the health system was already overstretched and people's health needs were already huge," says Ghassan Abou Chaar, MSF's head of mission in Yemen.
"To bring the outbreak under control, it won't be enough simply to treat those people who reach medical facilities. We also need to address the source of the disease, by improving water and sanitation and working in communities to prevent new cases."
The WHO says fewer than 45% of health facilities are fully functioning in Yemen, with almost 300 damaged or destroyed in fighting between forces loyal to President Abdrabbuh Mansour Hadi - who is backed by a Saudi-led multinational coalition - and those allied to the Houthi rebel movement.
Save the Children said all sides in the conflict should end restrictions on the import of aid immediately."

Humanitarian organizations have started to use UAVs, including in Haiti and the Philippines, for data collection and information tasks that include real time information and situation mon- itoring, public information and advocacy, search and rescue, and mapping.
• The most likely humanitarian application in the area of delivery and logistics would be delivery of small medical supplies, such as vaccines.
• The use of UAVs raises serious practical and ethical issues that humanitarian organizations must address through transparency, community engagement, and guidelines for privacy and data security.
• Developing safeguards and guidance for the use of UAVs in conflict settings, whether strictly for humanitarian purposes or for protection and human rights work, will be a significant chal- lenge. The humanitarian system should therefore focus on uses in natural disasters and early recovery settings.
• To tap into the growing interest in UAVs, particularly in technical communities, humanitarian organizations should engage in networks that promote good practices and guidance, and that can serve as a source of surge capacity.
• Despite their potential to enhance humanitarian operations, more research and evidence is needed to identify the comparative advantages of using UAVs. More research is needed on in- tegrating aerial observation and data collection into needs and damage assessments, search and rescue, and other humanitarian functions.
https://docs.unocha.org/sites/dms/Documents/Unmanned%20Aerial%20Vehicles%20in%20Humanitarian%20Response%20OCHA%20July%202014.pdf
_________________________________
COMMENTS:  The usefulness of the UAV is undeniable; Interest is building in the use of UAVs to assist in search and rescue, particularly when equipped with infrared, or other specialty cameras. For example, the European Union is fund- ing ICARUS, a research project to develop unmanned search and rescue tools to assist human teams. To be useful, the UAVs and trained sta  must be available within 24-48 hours of a sudden-onset disaster. In addition these technical approaches must be integrated into the protocols for rescue teams, agreements for importing dis- aster response equipment, the International Search and Rescue Advisory Group (INSARAG) guidelines and other areas of policy.
BUT there are challenges to an effective use of UAV. The biggest challenges to expanding the use of UAVs are legal and regulatory. In the OECD, most countries are just developing legal guidance for the commercial or civilian use of UAVs. Many countries in the global South, particularly those with large humanitarian caseloads, may have very little regulation at all. 
In the U.S., commercial unmanned aerial system (UAS) licenses were granted on a case-by-case basis, subject to approval by the FAA.27 Similar restrictions exist in the UK and EU.28 Many countries where humanitarians are working do not yet have legal frameworks, meaning that use of UAVs will probably need to be cleared on an ad hoc basis with local and national authorities. To ensure long-term acceptance of these tools it will be critical that humanitarians comply with all host country regulations and develop appropriate agreements with regulators. A particular issue is interference with traditional air tra ic: in many countries it is illegal to fly anything within 5km of a commercial airport. As humanitar- ian operations o en center around emergency airports and logistics hubs, these restrictions are of particular concern.
Other than the above there are also issues of:
Ethical procurement and partnerships
Privacy and data protection
Transparency, informed consent and community engagement
*** Ironing out all these issues takes time. While, like the consensus I do think it will be the thing of the future, this Q may close before all issues are solved.

It seems inevitable that this will be a useful resource to take advantage of. If Amazon can get stuff to us that quickly, why not take advantage of a way more productive method of safely delivering desperately needed aid to these areas especially if governments like Syria continue to hinder significant outside aid.

Global Atlanta, April 28, 'UPS Nurtures Its Founder’s Commitment to Innovation for 110 Years': http://www.globalatlanta.com/ups-nurtures-founders-commitment-innovation-110-years/
Clips from Global Atlanta article:
"We don’t envision that this great global infrastructure that we have created is going to go away and that there is not going to be a need for it, but you start looking at pockets,” he said, “There’s been a lot of hype about drones, but now the reality is beginning to step in.”
To start off, UPS has focused, he said, on the use of drones in humanitarian crises. In countries where the transportation infrastructure is poor, drones can be useful in delivering critical medical supplies. In an area affected by a natural disaster, drones may be able to deliver necessary equipment where a truck can’t go."
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.

NewsWorks, April 7, 'Cape May County to test how drones can aid post-disaster communications': http://www.newsworks.org/index.php/local/down-the-shore/102931-cape-may-county-to-test-how-drones-can-aid-post-disaster-communications-
Clips from article:
"Officials say the upcoming flight campaign will build on successful drone exercises held last year at the county airport, including using the aerial devices for similar communication provisions and surveying critical infrastructure. 
Also last year, Flirtey, a drone delivery service, conducted test flights to help determine whether drones can be used to carry human medical samples to and from areas during major natural disasters. The drones flew between an onshore medical relief camp and a test facility on a vessel stationed on the Delaware Bay.
"The use of this disruptive technology in supporting humanitarian and emergency operations is a major paradigm shift and significantly enhances the ability to support field medical operators and first responders in remote or otherwise inaccessible disaster sites," William Marshall, assistant vice president for government and military relations for NJIT, said during the Flirtey test. "The data captured here will be shared with all of the participants, including the FAA, in support of the agency's ongoing research into the integration of UAS into the national air space."
seems like a good idea - technology i s already practical

Reuters, Berlin: The International Humanitarian Society (IHS) and the Union of African War Fighter Pilots (UAFP) in Europe jointly protested together in front of the German Bundestag against the amendment of its foreign aid legislation. The protesters fear that their lines of business might dry up within months after the introduction of new UAV technology to the Bundeswehr and THW, a spokeswoman said. UAVs would be the most cost-effective choice of delivery for the Sub-Saharan theatre, the rapporteur of the dossier, Heinz Schröder of the ruling party (Christian Democrats), said in a press conference on Monday. IHS and UAFP were said to be in closed-door negotiations with the European Union and Germany to extract a government bail-out, as compensation for its business loss. The Coalition of Obsolete Industries (Australia) welcomed their initiative.
Many will try, some will succeed. The issue will be its efficacy.

The sector's commitment to innovation is likely to drive the application of these approaches to conflict zones although it is unlikely to be for mass delivery given the issues with weight.

The red cross is doing a project (in 2017) to investigate the possibilities of using drones for humanitarian aid in the wake of natural disasters. I imagine that project will include actual testing. However because we are not talking about a conflict zone there is less risk of losing the drone.   The risk of losing the drones and the aid not making it to the intended people are reasons why I don't think we will see a drone used to deliver humanitarian aid to a conflict zone in 2017.  Regardless, because the humanitarian crises become quite extreme, there is some chance those reasons will become moot.
This may provoke aggressor(s) into more violence.

Going a little lower than consensus and will reduce with time. The problem is that the drone must operate within a conflict zone. NGOs are unlikely to get permission to fly drones within a conflict zone, as a  humanitarian drone cannot easily be distinguished from an armed drone. It's not the same as delivering medications to remote villages in Rwanda, where Zipline has the government's permission.

Nasdaq, March 16, 'Gunmen attack aid convoy in South Sudan, killing two: IOM': http://www.nasdaq.com/article/gunmen-attack-aid-convoy-in-south-sudan-killing-two-iom-20170316-00802?utm_content=buffer2ac0e&utm_medium=social&utm_source=linkedin.com&utm_campaign=buffer
Clips from article:
"South Sudan has been mired in a conflict that has split the nation along ethnic lines and forced more than three million people to flee their homes. Aid workers have been kidnapped, shot at and had their supplies looted by armed men. The attack occurred on Tuesday near Yirol, in the centre of the country about 210 km (130 miles) northwest of the capital of Juba, where the aid workers had been dealing with a cholera outbreak. In a statement, the IOM said the convoy was targeted as it returned to Yirol, with the gunmen ambushing one of the vehicles. Two people died of gunshot wounds, the aid group said, and an IOM health officer was among the wounded. The identity and motivation of the attackers were unknown, the statement said. Also on Thursday, medical charity Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) said its hospital in Wau Shilluk had been looted during recent heavy fighting. "Wau Shilluk was looted of all medicines including life-saving drugs and essential supplies," Abdalla Hussein Abdalla, the deputy head of mission for South Sudan, said in a statement. "Our hospital is in a terrible condition."

The technology is there, but both NGO's and technology companies will want to time its use so that it gains maximum attention. The real question therefore is whether there will be a suitable disaster this year. It needs to be:
-Quite close to heavily populated areas so that lots of TV crews are around. Also close enough to infrastructure to enable UAV's to be flown out.
-An event that gains a lot of sudden attention and lots of disaster. Good weather, so flooding is out of the question. Basically has to be an earthquake, but not of the 9-Richter scale which desolates everything around. More like 7 Richter.
-A low-intensity conflict that makes it difficult for convoys to get across but no anti-aircraft fire.
-What is the probability of an earthquake that causes more than 1000 deaths in an unstable area? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_21st-century_earthquakes
2001 Gujarat, 2003 Bam, Iran, 2004 Pakistan, 2007 Kashmir, 2008 Pakistan, 2010 Afghanistan, 2011 Myanmar, 2013 Pakistan. 8 in 16 years, or 50%. Since there is pressure to deliver, I would nudge this up by a bit to 60%.
Yes it is already an viable option

seems pretty easy, no impediments to it other than a dictator shooting it down

The Cipher Brief, February 12, 'The New Technology of Humanitarian Assistance': https://www.thecipherbrief.com/article/tech/new-technology-humanitarian-assistance-1092
Clip from Cipher article:
"Potential advances in artificial intelligence (AI), however, could allow swarms of small drones to slip by air defense systems to individually deliver small packages of cargo—possibly even create impromptu networks for Wi-Fi and establish phone signal availability. Chow asserts that “as costs come down and AI-driven avionics accelerate in power, flotillas of drones over vulnerable regions can provide constant coverage for early detection and rapid response to humanitarian crises.” Artificially intelligent drones could also address major impediments to post-conflict reconstruction, such as landmine removal to enable locals to return to an agricultural economy while mitigating indiscriminate casualties largely affecting children. The Mine Kafon Drone seeks to autonomously map a designated area, detect the positioning of mines via GPS and then safely detonate them at a pace unmatched by even skilled personnel."
Delivery by drone reduces the risks.

Zipline Raises $25 Million to Expand Drone Delivery of Medical Supplies into Rwanda
by Alan Perlman on November 25, 2016

The first in its kind, this survey measures perceptions of the use of drones in humanitarian action.  The  Swiss  Foundation  for  Mine  Action  (FSD)  undertook  the  survey  between  15  November 2015 and 15 January 2016.
It has already happened, just not publicly disclosed.
The technology is definitely feasible and this would be cheaper and safer. Its a no brainer.
